string-array.name: milestones
string-array.item: Just a walk in the park
You\'re SnakeGo accomplishments will be recorded in the annals of history

resources.string:
Snake Poetry for our fellow SnakeGoers…

The appearance of a snake can evoke intense feelings of terror. And rightly so considering a snakebite can be so deadly. But beyond this visceral response, the snake is a multifaceted symbol. A little investigating reveals rich histories of the snake showing up in literature, art, and mythologies from around the world. Some of the following descriptions are among the most prevalent meanings attributed to the snake, despite cultural inflections: 

renewal, as snakes periodically shed their skin, spiritual and physical rebirth, resurrection, life, Mother Earth, pregnancy, primordial nature, the sea, good and evil, the sun and moon, power, knowledge, cunning, deceit, and death. Snakes are sometimes portrayed as guardians of treasure, esoteric knowledge, and the afterlife. They also connote venom, medicine, expanded consciousness, the elixir of life, and immortality.

In Greek mythology, Asclepius is a god of healing and medicine who carries a snake entwined staff. The rod of Asclepius as its often called can be found throughout the world on flags and emblems of distinguished medical institutions, such as the World Health Organization and the American Medical Association. The rod of Asclepius is sometimes confused with the Caduceus, a rod with wings and two snakes wrapped around it, carried by the Greek god Hermes. Although their meanings overlap, when two snakes are coiled around each other (or a staff in this case), this tends to signify the union of opposing forces, similar to the yin and the yang. 

Similarly, the Ouroboros is a well-known example of snake iconography which depicts a snake eating its tail. This represents cyclic manifestation, re-absorption, wholeness, Earth, and the infinite.

The snake is widely considered to be synonymous with the serpent. In some East Asian cultures, there's no distinction between snakes, serpents, and dragons. 

With so many meanings attached to the snake, it's a difficult creature to pin down, figuratively. How does the snake fit into our lives? Why do we impart such significance to the snake? We see its frequent recurrence - in art, movies, and literature? 

One element of the snake's appeal is arguably its difficulty in being pinned down. The mysticism that surrounds the snake comes at least in part from its skin shedding trait. The snake's impression of continual regeneration combined with the terror, awe, and mystery of its lethal venom is a paradox that parallels life. Deep questions remain about the meaning of life. These are often wrapped in metaphors, symbols, and contradictions. As a wise person once said, "to live is to suffer… to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering." Ascribing some meaning to the snake is one way we have survived. Many of life's paradoxes lie outside our ability to understand. They are better left as symbols that refer to that which we don't understand. This can offer us some humility and peace. In one manifestation of snake iconography, the Ouroboros, life eats life, creating death… changing, evolving, self-generating… this captures a lasting conundrum that radiates out (and in) - beyond to infinity, residing in a timeless place, and constituting an unnameable transcendence. As such, the snake stays. 

SnakeGo



















 
















Sources 

Wikipedia 

An Illustrated Encyclopedia of Traditional Symbols by J.C. Cooper 

The Power of Myth by Joseph Campbell 

Dictionary.com
